awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Bayesian Methods for the Data-Driven Recovery of Networks: Measuring Impact and Building Resilience in Infrastructures and Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The US government has increasingly emphasized resilience planning for critical infrastructure, where the combination of withstanding and recovering from disruptions that exacerbate our aging and vulnerable infrastructure systems, constitutes resilience. According to the Department of Homeland Security, the resilient operation of critical infrastructures is "essential to the Nation's security, public health and safety, economic vitality, and way of life." Of particular interest recently is an emphasis on the resilience of communities after a disruptive event, acknowledging that infrastructures do not exist for their own sake but serve society (e.g., citizens, industries), and in some cases, resilient communities assist in protecting the built environment. A resilient community would ideally be able to use the physical infrastructure to effectively communicate risk and coordinate recovery strategies to respond to and recover from disruptions, and ultimately adapt to change and learn from past disruptions. The objective of this work is to develop a new data-driven optimization framework to improve (i) the ability to model the performance of infrastructure networks, and (ii) the ability to plan for the recovery of these networks after a disruption, with an emphasis on community resilience and economic productivity. 

The research approach is composed of three components. The first component develops a new statistical technique, the hierarchical Bayesian kernel method, which integrates the Bayesian property of improving predictive accuracy as data are dynamically obtained, the kernel function that adds specificity to the model and can make nonlinear data more manageable, and the hierarchical property of borrowing information from different sources in sparse and diverse data situations which are common in disruptive events scenarios. The second component develops an infrastructure network recovery optimization formulation that minimizes the larger impact of infrastructure network performance with data-driven (and dynamically updated) hierarchical Bayesian kernel parameters of infrastructure recovery, along with solution techniques that account for the size and dynamic nature of model parameters. The application of the first two integrated components to electric power networks (where impact is measured on the safety and resilience of the community) and inland waterways (where impact is measured on economic productivity across multiple industries), constitutes the third component, offering two application perspectives on the impact of infrastructure network resilience and recovery.

por.por_cntn:
According to the Department of Homeland Security, the resilient operation of critical infrastructures is "essential to the Nation's security, public health and safety, economic vitality, and way of life." As such, critical infrastructure systems do not exist for their own sake but to serve society, and in some cases, resilient communities assist in protecting the built environment. A resilient community would ideally be able to use the physical infrastructure to effectively communicate risk and coordinate recovery strategies to respond to and recover from disruptions, and ultimately adapt to change and learn from past disruptions. To better prepare for future disasters and build resilient systems, this project focused on improving our ability to recover infrastructure systems and communities after a disruption. Specifically, the research addressed challenges related to the data availability and the uncertainty under which these systems perform during disruptions. In addition, several applications of the developed methods were explored and helped better understand the performance of power systems, water distribution networks, and inland waterway navigation during and after disruptions.

The project resulted in new statistical methods that addressed fundamental challenges in predictive modeling that are specific to risk analysis problems where data is limited and timely decisions are critical. We developed two methods to address challenges of small data and computational efficiency: (i) the hierarchical Bayesian kernel model which provides more accurate results in less computation time, and (ii) the approximate Gibbs sampler which efficiently learns model parameters without compromising the accuracy.  While the new methods can be used in different contexts, we applied them to predict community resilience to power outages and evaluate water distribution serviceability under flood and earthquake hazards. We have also collaborated with other researchers to develop optimization frameworks that guide such allocation of resources before and after a disaster. Specifically, we developed optimization frameworks that incorporate organizational and socioeconomic aspects to support operational decisions aimed at improving the resilience of infrastructure systems. We also developed models to optimize the integrated mitigation and restoration planning of interdependent infrastructure networks and we proposed heuristic techniques that overcome the computational challenge of this complex problem. The new methods were applied to guide the allocation of resources before and after a disaster to recover a set of interdependent infrastructure systems including power, water, and gas networks in Shelby County, TN. Finally, we have consolidated more than 1000 community resilience indicators into a classification scheme to help researchers and operators identify and select the best indicator to evaluate community resilience.

The outcomes of this work improve real-time decision-making during disasters to strategically allocate resources towards the restoration of infrastructure and the recovery of communities. This project also contributed to training the next generation of engineers through the integration of research outcomes in classroom teaching and the professional development of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students including students from underrepresented groups in STEM.
